conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a region where the light is not present.
The size and shape of the shadow depend on the position of the light source relative to the object and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
The light source is initially positioned above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
The shadows are elongated due to the angle of the light source.
When the light source moves backward, it changes the angle at which the light rays hit the objects.
The new position of the light source will result in a different angle of incidence for the light rays.
As the light source moves backward, the shadows will shift forward.
The shadows will move in the direction opposite to the movement of the light source.
When the light source moves backward, the angle of the light rays becomes more perpendicular to the ground.
This results in shorter shadows because the light rays are hitting the objects more directly.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will move forward on the ground.
The shadows will become shorter due to the more perpendicular angle of the light rays.
When the light source moves backward above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will move forward on the ground and become shorter.
